"Non Scientists like being right -- they like when things turn out the way that they expected. But Scientists, on the other hand, they want things to work out not the way they expected"

Well, let's see if he is a Scientist or a Non-Scientist -- because things are not as he believes; That statement is FALSE. It is too much fanboying over "Scientists". Will he like or dislike this?

I come to this after working with Scientists -- who I know personally and who I have observed, absolutely and with great passion, wanting things to go as they expect.

One really strong example of this Robert Millikan, who so wanted things to go the way he expected that in his famous oil drop experiment he would entirely ignore measurements that were contrary to his expected results. Basically he fabricated his results and this has led to some quiet complaints of fraud. The one problem is that the results he published were almost perfectly correct and they would have been wrong if he included the observations he ignored. He knew what result he should get and when he did not get that result -- he ignored and hid those results.

He is a scientist. And he did NOT like it when things turned out differently than expected. He is not alone. Many of them hate that.

On the other hand, comedy is enjoyed by both scientists and non-scientists. And comedy is an art that relies, almost exclusively, on the unexpected. It is the unexpected that makes comedy work. So clearly, at least sometimes non-scientists like it when things do not go as they expected.

The error in the statement is the use of the word "like". Instead, what he should have said was that the difference between scientists and non-scientists is that scientists make use of PATTERNS in unexpected behavior to learn new things and non-scientists generally do not.

One very underrated takeaway from this is that it is often easy to think that all the big discoveries have already been made and now most discovery is of smaller things. A moment's thought about basically anything will reassure you that this is far from true, but it's especially reassuring to note that FRBs, hugely powerful radio source events that happen quite frequently in the universe, have only been known about for a scant 13 years. In the history of science, that's really a blink, and it means that we are still very actively discovering the really big stuff. We are FAR from done. :-)

Maybe I'm missing something, but if you are only measuring the Lyman - alpha forest or even the dispersion difference of these high-intensity radio pulses, you are only measuring the baryonic matter that exist between you and that light/EM source. Like spokes on a wheel, with the earth being the central point. If the stars and light sources were homogenously scattered in a perfect sphere around the earth such that a beam of light passed through all matter in the universe before it reached you, then this would be a good measurement, but it isn't, and thus, there may be no light sources that pass through some of the matter that exist out there, especially if there is matter beyond the farthest light source that exist on the fringes of this sphere; an outer sphere of matter with no light source behind it, so to speak. Accounting for the curving of light by gravity, it seems possible that light could even bend around certain matter such that an incident ray of light never reaches us.  Lastly, the edge of the universe that we can see depends is dependent on the speed of light and the amount of time that has passed since that light was emitted. If the universe is 14 something billions years old, we can only see light from a distance equal to the distance the speed of light can travel in those 14 billion years; anything 15 billion light years away would not have reached us until another billion years from now, and thus your calculations of the total matter in the universe will continue to grow each year.  If the edge of the universe is truly 14 billion light years away, we are only seeing the light from the very beginning of it's existence (it will be another 14 billion yrs before we see the what exists on that edge in 2021 Earth time), and won't know until at least several more thousand or million years go by to confirm nothing exists further out.

Ok, so astronomers, scientists, and physicists can prove mathematically and with empirical evidence that the light left over from the Big Bang event that created our Universe is detectable by the most sensitive instruments attached to the largest telescopes we have today. These instruments have detected light from events that occurred only 150 million years after the Big Bang. I get that.

So we arrive here, in this part of the universe and we point a telescope in some direction and collect that light. If matter moves slower than light, how did we get here, to this point in the universe, BEFORE the light from the big bang got here? We gathered this very old light in telescopes and analysed that data to come to the conclusion that we are witnessing the light from events that occurred when the very first galaxies were beginning to form from the primordial clouds of hydrogen released very near to the beginning of time and space. But how did we get here, to this point in space, first?

I understand collecting light from events millions of years ago. Light takes a long time to travel across the vast distances of interstellar space. But collecting the light from billions of years ago? 14.55 billion years ago to be more precise?

It took 14.7 billion years for us to get here, in this part of our expanding universe. Did not the light from the big bang precede us? And if we know where to point a telescope to peer into the distant past, are we looking towards the center of the expanding universe, or out to the edge? If we can gather the light coming to us from the center of the universe (which is light that is 14.7B minus 150M years old) that means we got here BEFORE the light. And there must be, at some point in that direction, only DARKNESS, no light coming to us, because the light on the other side of the center of the universe has to travel FARTHER than 14.7 billion light years to where we are, and is spreading outward from that central point, travelling for the last 14.7 billion years. How does it get here after we do? And, at what point do we find the darkness, that area farther away from us than the center of the universe, where light must take more than the age of the universe to reach us?

Our universe is expanding at the speed of light. Has been for 14.7 billion years. The width of the universe then, is the speed of light * 14.7 billion years * 2 = 2.78139535 × 10^26 meters.

That is approximately 2,781,395,350,000,000,000,000 Kilometers from one side of the Universe to the other side. And getting wider every second. About 600,000 kilometers wider every second.

You made an interesting observation about the difference between scientists and non-scientists, in that you feel like "non-scientists like being right", while "scientists... want things to work out not the way they expected." I understand where you're coming from, but I'm not sure I totally agree. I mean, the goal of a scientist is largely to discover and understand, right? In order to know they're on the right track, they often need to test their understanding. Either by doing some math or performing some experiment, they sometimes want to check their work, and do something from which they think they can accurately predict the result. While those particular tests can be intriguing or illuminating if the results were unexpected (especially since an incorrect assertion can often result in pointing one in the right direction), if those results are always not what was expected, then it probably means they're not learning anything about what they're studying. So I think you're partially right, but I don't know by how much, haha. Because scientists can't really know when an unexpected result is more valuable than an expected one, it might be more accurate to say that scientists typically try to suspend their sense of value in being right or wrong, while non-scientists are specifically seeking expected outcomes or being right, in order to prove what they assume they already know.

This is a "triumph" to the very few individuals who have careers dependent on this type of research. It's "somewhat interesting" to a somewhat-larger group of people (I suppose the people watching this video). It's useless for nearly everyone else.

This is not to belittle the research - it just provides perspective on the value it creates.

Maybe it's something MUCH simpler than that. If energy is the same thing as matter (that is what Einstein proved with E=mc2) then maybe we should be looking for other forms of energy, like ELECTRICITY. I NEVER heard astronomers talk about the electric currents in the universe. I have them instantly dismiss the idea of an electric universe tho. But maybe their idea of the electric universe is wrong. We KNOW that magnetic and electronic forces go hand in hand, that is exactly how we make all electricity on this planet. And since most of the bodies we find in our own solar system are involved with magnetic fields, then why wouldn't they also have electrical fields? The Earth has a 'magneto-sphere' correct? Then why can't it have an 'electro-sphere'? (I am WAY over simplifying this of course) If i can take a few magnets and run them through coils of wire i get electricity, but the magnetic field of Earth doesn't create electricity? If it did then this energy would have mass, correct? (i'm guessing everyone will say no) Well maybe there is enough electrical current/charge throughout the universe to make up for all this 'missing' mass.... and what about plasma? That reacts to magnetic fields, right? Well maybe all this electrical current is containing plasma around the galaxies. It's just not the super energetic/hot plasma we usually think of (and it's not emitting light) and it could be surrounding the galaxies like a cocoon, causing it to spin the way we see (the way astronomers say 'dark matter' surround them) - this could fix the whole dark matter problem the way I see it - but what do I know right? Of course, this is based on the assumption that the CMB is the result of the epoch of last scattering. If we consider the hypothesis that the CMB is what we assume it to be, and then test that hypothesis, and find it does not predict the amount of baryons that we would expect, then ideally that hypothesis would have just been falsified. Instead, the hypothesis is held to be true, and the failure to detect what it predicts isn't treated as an instance of falsification, but instead an as an instance of something missing that should be there (this is largely the same reason that dark matter and dark energy have been predicted). Of course, this is a perfect example of the fact that the idealised notion of scientific falsifiability isn't actually how science works. Theories are falsified all the time, and kept around regardless. A more accurate description of how science works is that there is some kind of selection procedure that selects from available theories to see which one is the "best"; if a theory is falsified, it doesn't matter if there isn't another theory around that is then considered "better". Of course, the problem of what makes something better can be quite unscientific. For example, with the missing baryon problem, there was another hypothesis that accurately predicted the observed energy density of the CMB, without introducing a missing baryon problem, by arguing that the CMB was the result of a specific class of aged star output, rather than the result of the Epoch of last scattering from the big bang. Unfortunately, a significant reason why some theories aren't considered "better" is due simply to fashion and group think.

It's important to note that warm-hot models of the universe are not hugely accepted, so detecting so called "missing matter" on the basis of such a model isn't exactly strong evidence. I haven't read the paper, but I would bet that the data can only be interpreted to cover the missing baryon problem if the warm-hot model is assumed to be true, as this is the way most of cosmology works right now (too many free variables that can't be controlled in a direct fashion).

Here's a very interesting fact: the entire basis of modern cosmology, of which all observational measurements are unavoidably tainted by, due to the necessity of strong data interpretation in cosmology, are based on the notion that distance correlated redshift is due to a Doppler shift like effect (i.e. things are redshifted because they are expanding away from us. This is another instance where it's sort of just been maintained because it's the "best" explanation we had at the time; but the actual direct evidence that conforms to this explanation is in reality closely matched by direct evidence that falsifies this explanation. And in general, considering the fact that the entirety of modern cosmology rests on this relationship being true, there has been relatively little work done to actually to directly test it, which can be done using relativity tests.

It's all well and good to say that scientists love being wrong; but the inability for professions like cosmology to entertain opposing theories, such as static or steady state models, means that opposing theories are simply never developed well enough, and instead of failed predictions being considered "falsifications", they are just considered "missing stuff", in light of the fact that the profession doesn't entertain other theories enough for them to be developed enough to compete.

I encourage you to cover some issues with modern cosmology, and underdeveloped opposing theories that don't produce problems of "missing" stuff. Because if there's never any competing theories, then a theory by definition can not ever be wrong, simply because of the large interpretation bias in cosmology that doesn't exist in other sciences that can perform more controlled experiments.

Scientists shouldn't be lionised any more than any other group; they're still flawed people that are susceptible to group think and fashion as with anyone else. The reality is that direct tests of expansion don't appear to prefer static theories any less than they prefer expansion theories. For example, tolman surface brightness and angular size tests tests only match with expansion if very aggressive and fined tuned galaxy evolution is introduced to account for discrepancies; meanwhile, a static universe fits these test with no need for fine tuning of galaxy evolution.

Some holes in the background assumptions. . .
====================================================================
1. The "Cosmic Background Radiation" seems to disappear if your "detector" is shielded from the oceans by being far enough inland and surrounded by mountains. Ref: Herouni Radio-Optical Telescope, Yerevan, Armenia. . . no CMBR. . . anywhere.
====================================================================
2. Red Shift can not be used for expanding universe arguments. . . Halton Arp. . . 250 exceptions to the argument. . . the kinds of exemptions that astronomers could not deal with. . . "Red shift" on one side of a galaxy and "Blue Shift" on the the other side of that same galaxy. . . not physically possible.
====================================================================
3. There is NO explanation allowing for the compression of any form of Hydrogen gas or any form of Helium gas to the near-metalic levels of compression to create academically acceptable stars. . . they like to spread out but they do NOT like to be compressed. Try it in any lab and you will come to the same conclusion. There is also NO POSSIBLE EXPLANATION for how the "supposed theoretical process" could have been accomplished isothermically. IF the theoretic compression process was not "processed" isothermically, you would cross the "trigger temperature" that would light up the Hydrogen as a Hydrogen Bomb. . . exeunt every star that might try an adiabatic compression process. They would light up as Hydrogen Bombs every time. . . no exceptions.
====================================================================
4. IF there was a "Big Bang". . . and that's a BIG IF. . . the only other candidate for potential star formation would have to be Lithium. Lithium is solid enough to be something that could be gathered as a core for a first generation star. But the gasses, Hydrogen or Helium, not possible.
=====================================================================
5. Dark Matter is a mathematical construct. . . basically a glorified "fudge factor". It doesn't actually exist. The math works out just fine. But that doesn't mean that an imagined substance is actually there.
=====================================================================
6. Dark Energy is also a mathematical construct. . . also a glorified "fudge factor". . . for an "expanding universe" that isn't actually "expanding".
=====================================================================
7. The matter-antimatter question considered in this video assumes a "Big Bang" in which matter exploded in the Eastern direction and antimatter exploded in the Western direction. . . basically "away" from each other. IF the Big Bang had not happened as assumed, for purposes of this discussion, the protons and antiprotons would have "eaten" each other. . . ie. . . Big Bang + Big Boing = Big ZERO. . . no universe created. So if the Big Bang actually did happen, they would have to avoid each other somehow. Going in opposite directions would have been the only way such a thing would have been possible.
=====================================================================

Derek, what you're talking about at 12:05 is very easy to explain: Its because scientists and scientifically-minded people think in riddles/puzzles.
Consider this: Once a puzzle has been solved, then is it still interesting? For the scientist, it isnt. It loses interest as soon as its solved, therefore a new puzzle has to be found and solved. Solving the puzzle is the interesting part, specifically because its a challenge, in provokes the mind, its an intellectual mountain that has to be climbed.

So, for the scientifically-minded person, its the puzzle that matters, while for the non-scientist, they just want the solution/answer.

I have heard several times that idea that scientists are happier when they are wrong, but I don't buy it. It is an idealization, not reality. Scientists are human, and therefore moved by the same human desires and ambitions, even if they direct them to a goal quite different than the average joe. No scientist makes an experiment (at least if it is not rutirary, or in line with a rival theory, etc) expecting to be wrong. They expect to be right, to success, not to fail. Human psyche at work. This does not invalidate that they're (on average) more open-minded and could (later) get a right from a wrong (Alexander Fleming, for example), but that's another story. "I prefer to be wrong" is not the first thought in anyone's mind.

Great video as always! One small suggestion to avoid misunderstanding:

The Lyman-alpha forest graph at 5:50 should not develop dips at different wavelengths as the light interacts with hydrogen clouds on its journey to us, as this suggests that the hydrogen is absorbing different wavelengths of light which is not happening. More accurately, the graph should only ever develop troughs at 121.6nm (as the lyman-alpha absorption/re-emission transition only happens at this wavelength), and then the whole graph should move rightward to represent redshift before hitting another hydrogen cloud to develop its next trough again at 121.6nm.

A small but important distinction!

It sort of makes sense that half the matter in the universe is in diffuse gas clouds from a thermodynamic point of view.

When a star forms, it's entropy decreases because the star is much more organized than the gas cloud it formed from. In order for entropy to decrease overall, the outer portion of the gas cloud is ejected and becomes more diffuse and higher entropy than when it started.

It seems a similar thing is happening on a universal scale. When the random particles after the big bang formed ordered structures like galaxies, they had to dispel large quantities of high entropy, ultra diffuse gas in order to ensure overall entropy increase.

Saturn's satellite called "Titan" has a methane atmosphere, impossible in an old universe (the sun breaks down methane fast).  Jupiter is still hot, VERY hot, impossible in an old universe.  Jupiter's satellite "IO" is extremely volcanicly active, impossible if the universe were as old as they say.  Saturn's rings are slowly moving away from Saturn, proving it is not that old or they would have been gone by now.  Our moon is slowly moving away from Earth making an old universe impossible.  The evidence against an old universe and in favor of a young one is abundant.  The evidence for a universe billions of years old and a big bang is non-existent.  For a good video which goes over all the planets and satellites ("moons") in our solar system and the evidence against a big bang and old universe, search Youtube for "Spike Psarris Solar System", he's a former NASA engineer, great video where he presents scientific evidence, which is well known. Why 5%. Because the math needs 5% to make sense. Um, how do we know the math is right to begin with? It you start with a broken theory, and then force the math to work, and then observe something different than what the math said it has to be, maybe the theory is wrong. Until recently, logic led the math. Now math leads everything. Used to be you'd come up with a idea than might explain how things work, then set out to do the math to see if you can prove that idea works. I know there have been examples of seemingly useless math solutions that led to technological breakthroughs later, but the big theories like those of Newton, Faraday, and Einstein led with logic, not math.

The graphics and explanation for the whistlers are just bad. And the verbiage given initially sounds like it came from the Wikipedia entry for Whistlers, which is also pretty poor. Showing photons (EM waves) following a magnetic field (in this case the Earth's) is just wrong. In classical EM electric and magnetic fields just add (in other words, magnetic fields do not bend the path of photons.)

What causes whistlers to be heard on the other side of the world from a lightening strike is analogous to why we can hear AM radio stations from far away, in the evening and at night. In that case the AM band waves bounce off of an ionized part of the atmosphere. In the case of whistlers we are also hearing bounced electromagnetic waves, from charged particles even higher off the surface of the earth. The magnetosphere is indeed caused by the Earth's magnetic field, but the lightening's emitted radio waves bounce off of the plasma, not follow magnetic lines.

Here's a useless bit of trivia

That radiotelescope shown at 3:57 is located at the La Silla observatory in northern Chile and is actually abandoned, sort of.

Nowadays a single antenna can do very little compared to the large arrays we use now, like the one at ALMA. So this retro instrument has been sitting in that same position for decades, and the electronics in it are just as old, which adds to the expense they would have to face to even try to make it useful again.

Its reflector stuck in an horizontal position makes it really photogenic though, so you'll often see photos or timelapses of it, always pointed down to the horizon rather than the sky.

While Veritasium often does a good job describing complex topics, we need to talk about the sloppy use of the phrase "big bang".  It's a troublesome phrase, overlain (or underlaid) with religious baggage.  And the phrase has had shades of meaning in scientific circles.   Here, Veritasium is using it as a synonym for the (problematic) singularity if one runs the expansion clock back far enough.  However, lecturers and presenters now often use "big bang" to just refer to the process that led up to the surface of last scattering (i.e., the CMB source.)  This is one of the awkward complexities that arise when trying to communicate contemporary cosmology to an audience that has been programmed  with religious and/or errant popularizations (as in TV, film, etc.)
